Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity to Produce Culturally Competent STEM Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through funding support from a Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Capacity Building grant, the "Building Capacity to Produce Culturally Competent STEM Teachers" project will develop secondary teacher preparation programs in physics, chemistry, biology, mathematics and interdisciplinary physical sciences. Robust degree programs aimed at producing well-prepared high school teachers in fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) are a national priority that underpin progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. Placing successful STEM teachers in high-need school districts and ensuring the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields are essential. This Noyce project will address this critical need through developing programs, curriculum, and pedagogies that incorporate effective, research-based practices in STEM disciplinary fields and that include preservice teacher training in cultural awareness and social justice.

Because this project will be led by Texas Lutheran University (TLU), a small Hispanic-serving liberal arts college, it will establish the infrastructure to produce uniquely trained middle and high school STEM teachers, prepared to serve in rural, high-need school districts in south central Texas. New collaborations among faculty in science, mathematics and education, coupled with expansion of education partnerships with south central Texas high-need school districts will serve as a foundation for the project. As a part of the project's efforts in developing the STEM teacher preparation degree plans, collaborations will be established between TLU science, mathematics and education departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, “Building Capacity to Produce Culturally Competent STEM Teachers,” aimed to expand not only the number, but the quality and effectiveness of middle and high school STEM teachers to teach in the high needs districts of south central Texas. Several new STEM degree programs were developed, forging new collaborations between TLU STEM and Education faculty who worked together to creat innovative recruitment and retention strategies that invite STEM majors to consider teaching as a career option. In developing curricular and extracurricular components of the program leading to secondary certification in several STEM fields, we have developed a manageable, impactful program that places the issue of diversity within the STEM classroom. The degree programs will prepare teachers with the tools to do the same in their own classrooms. This model will be highly valuable to others with the similar aspirations, with particular interest to other small liberal arts institutions. The issue of making an impact on the face of science and truly influencing diversity in STEM fields has been elusive, even to the best scientists. By developing programs for preparing STEM teachers, equipped with cultural sensitivity and knowledgeable about issues of social justice as they relate to STEM fields, we impact the diversity of those participating in science, an overall benefit to science. Our innovative program goes beyond the required rigorous disciplinary content with training in the most recent recommendations for effective science/math pedagogies, and enrichment in cultural sensitivity, social justice and the ideologies of scientific citizenship as a STEM concern.  

 

We have developed several new degree plans and revised the two existing STEM degrees leading to secondary teacher certification. Most notable is the development of a new multidisciplinary course, cross listed in all four TLU STEM departments and team taught by STEM faculty mentors and TLU Science Education faculty. This new upper division STEM course allows for a light reduction in the large number of hours needed for the lab-intensive chemistry, physics and biology STEM degrees.
